author: cheechyuan.eth
content: Hi everyone, Im CheeChyuan and Im from Malaysia. Im a web developer and have taken interest in the blockchain space a few years back. Previously had played with IBM's hyperledger fabric and also written smart contracts on the kovan testnet as POC for a voting app that was used in a local university here in Malaysia.

author: sabnock
content: Hello everyone. My name is James from the US. I'm a software developer and I've followed the cryptocurrency space since late 2017 and used to be highly skeptical of Eth but have since changed my mind on it.

author: sabnock
content: I've been going through the yellow paper and my math background and the blockchain course I took in university have definitely served me well.

author: theamarishow
content: Hi Everyone. My name is Juan and I'm originally from Argentina. I've been a software engineer for about 5 years now with a background in distributed processing and data science. I'm happy to meet you all üôÇ

author: 0xrobertocantu
content: Hey everyone, I'm Roberto. I live in Texas in the States. I was previously on a path to be a licensed architect (buildings, construction, etc.) until I was introduced to crypto in the 2017 bull run. Naturally, I came across and learned about Ethereum and knew I wanted to pivot to the space full time at some point. Now I'm a developer and have deployed some contracts to various testnets and have participated in some hackathons, as well. Glad to be here amongst all of you. üòé

author: abstract_man
content: Hi everyone, My name is Darcy and I am originally from China. I graduated from college last year and currently a software developer. I just started learning about blockchain and I think Ethereum could very likely be the future as I learn all the cool stuff about it! Glad to meet you allüçâ

author: soodmax
content: Hi everyone, my name is Atul and I am from Canada. I'm a software engineer by trade and spent first half of my career in enterprise architecture and development, last few years in various leadership roles. Still very much excited about technology, programming and the future of Ethereum and its impact on business landscape. Happy to be here!

author: lightclient
content:
If anyone is looking for some small tasks to start getting their hands dirty <@689161464829050960> and I have been working on an EVM assembler/disassembler. There are several open tickets of varying degrees of difficulty: https://github.com/quilt/etk/issues

Feel free to try and tackle any of them!

author: odyslam
content: Hey, super interesting. Thanks for sharing! BTW, how come and the implementation is in rust? It seems to be gaining in popularity in the space versus others like Golang

author: odyslam
content: I have been working in the DevOps space for about a year now and everyone here is about Golang, so I am curiousüòÖ

author: lightclient
content: Golang is a great language for building awesome things quickly, but if you want maximum performance rust is best. I find the toolchain more pleasant to work with as well. Cargo is amazing!

author: odyslam
content: I have been meaning to get my hands dirty with rust for some time, thanks for the insight! yeah, about performance, that's true. I am mostly curious because I see people creating CLI-type tools with rust, for which I imagine performance is not an issue

author: odyslam
content: for example, I could see why you want an eth node in rust

author: spiralglide
content: I'm not the most well versed in Rust, but I might take a minute to look around the source code and maybe contribute.

author: spiralglide
content: Golang and Rust, from my experience, have similar diseases of that their best design decisions are their biggest pains

author: spiralglide
content: Though I think that tends to apply to almost everything in the world nowadays

author: samwilsn
content: Eh, I feel like Rust's pain points are more because some features aren't done yet, and not because of design decisions, but I'm horribly biased.

author: samwilsn
content: Looking at you higher-kinded types, const-generics, async traits, etc
